reviewText:
Nail'd may be the best $1.24 I've ever spent on Steam.

This game plays like the classic PS2 game ATV Offroad Fury, with better graphics, bigger maps, and a turbo on your ATV.

Disclaimer: This is not real racing. You spend as much time in the air as you do on the ground. You can steer your vehicle in the air.

But hot damn, it's fun. It lacks 2-player support. The soundtrack isn't the best. But the game is a blast to play, and it *does* support my Xbox controller. Try the demo.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ND4r1ApjPrU&list=UUnQL0hzRCQwxnRMV9Nn9i6g

In Nail'd you will crash a lot, at least in the beginning, maybe even accompanied with some cursing, but you after learn the tracks, both will be reduced. But lets not jump ahead to the gameplay and continue with the options. There are a lot video option (texture quality, material quality, shadows, texture filtering  and so on) to make the game run on slower machines. The game came out in 2010 and I can safely say it looks decent 4 years later.

I was quite surprise from the audio option. You can manage every sound in the game – engine, music in game and in the menus, environment and so on. As a hole the audio is okay. The engines sound okay and the music is decent, fits really well with the game. Also you can adjust the brightness and rebind keys on the keyboard. And honestly, you need to, because by default they are weird. You can play with 360 controller, but controls are absolutely fine with the keyboard.

After you set up all the option, it's time to choose male or female character, some clothes for them and atv or dirt bike. For your driver customizations are limited just to clothes, but you can change parts on your vehicle. They are unlocked just by playing the game and they have advantages and disadvantages.

The gameplay is arcade. Here the gravity is not the master. What I mean is, you can do extremely ridiculous jumps. And the sense of speed is amazing. This maybe is one of the few games where I don't mind the motion blur. Even if I want to I can't turn it off. In the beginning, before I get used to the sense of speed, I often missed some turns. Interesting thing in the gameplay is the steering in the air and leaning to adjust your jump. In other words – you almost fly.

There are 4 types of races – single lap, 3 laps, time challenge and stunt race. The first 3 are self explanatory. The stunt race is a little bit different. They are not stunts in a traditional sense. In this mode points are given if you drive through fire gates and circles, make wheelie and few others. And of course, here also matter if you finish in first place and how much you were in front of the other players. That way you can win a race, even if you didn't make enough stunts. All of them give you boost. My favorite way of getting it is to fall down on someone or push them in to obstacles. This can happen to you too. Other interesting thing is the mutators. They are constant boost or no collision.

To work everything I said about the gameplay, you need really good tracks. This is the case here. The design is great, even the environments are good – village, harbor, forest, canyon and others. Every track have different routs to take, but not all of them are shortcuts. Also in some tracks there are obstacles like falling rocks, but they are easily avoidable and stop being a surprise after a while.

One of the things I didn't like is the difficulty. I played on medium. The first half of the game I didn't have any problems with the AI. Then the difficulty jumps high for a few tracks. After them I was winning every race again without a problem. But biggest issue here is the repetition. It's kind get boring after a while, because there isn't enough variety. Since this is old game the online multiplayer is dead, but if you have some friends there is LAN, it's such rare thing to see these days.

I never played racing game with such sense of speed and adrenalin. Some compare it to MotorStorm. Even with the repetition, which comes at some point, this is still a solid game. If you have friends to play it gets even better. I recommend it.

I'm bored today. so I'm going to do another review.

Sooooo...you DEFINITELY maybe want to get this game...if it's on sale for $1.
This game is like FUEL on an acid trip, like Burnout if it were obsessed with catching air, and like my friend is with his 'your mom' jokes, just doesn't know WHEN TO STOP sometimes.
Nail'd is a fun game, and I really like it. but just for short bursts.

CONS:
- it's all about dat racing (there are a few challenges and modifiers throughout tournament mode, but nothing that changes your core objective, to be 1st place)
- 3 laps takes too long on some of the courses (for a filthy casual like me)
- rockin' music thinks it's better than it is (OR they just need more songs on rotation)
- online multiplayer doesn't function

PROS:
> catch EXTREME AIR
> have a lot of boost/nitro capacity
> customizable clothing, gear, equipment, vehicles
> you can kinda run other racers off the road so they crash into stuff & that's kinda awesome

So as you can tell, I'm kind of divided on this game. Personally, I wish there was more variety to the game, like with different modes (combat-based, mini-games, et cetera) or perhaps a free-roam mode (what can I say, I loved FUEL). But that said, the core game in Nail'd is still strong and fun for what it is.

TL;DR= If I had to pick: It is a NO for me at regular price. And a CAUTIOUS YES for me IF IT'S ON SALE (for 1 dollar or less). However, if you really like arcade-y, EXtreme-air type offroad RACING games that almost make you feel like you have super-powers, then it could be a (stronger) YES recommendation for you. :)

reviewText: If there's one game genre that keeps getting outdone by itself, it has to be racing games.nail'd is of the latest games in that arms race.And after spending a while with simulators where you're trying to find a tenth of a second on one corner, nothing could be as refreshing as a racing game where you spend around one quarter of the time on the track, well, off the track - in the air. nail'd delivers high-flying racing on ATVs and motocross bikes, and while it purposely skips things like performing stunts, its seemingly drug-induced brand of ridiculous racing hardly needs any of that to be exciting.Playing nail'd is like controlling a Choose Your Own Adventure rollercoaster with a gamepad. Its tracks have massive ups and downs, completely unrealistic verticals - like not just crossing a canyon, but actually diving down into it, and landing it perfectly - and a sense of speed that's unparalleled in the motocross racing genre.nail'd does come with some downsides, though. While the tracks are fantastic and have lots of routes for you to go through, the developers often actually punish you for going too fast or too high, as you'll often crash into stuff in mid-air if you're going too fast.Despite the lack of depth to your racing strategy, nail'd is still a blast and a half for at least a while, and the online play works nicely - if you can find people online to play with, that is. The console versions are fine, but the PC version of the game was completely devoid of players on launch day.Nail'd is arcade driving taken to the extreme. A fun game over all, which engages you tu run and jump at incredible velocities.

reviewText:
Nail'd is an insane, over-the-top crash&burn racer something like Burnout in feel, but on ATV or MTX vehicles.

The Chrome Engine is used to great effect here. It looks gorgeous and runs butter smooth. The handling model is appropriately arcade, with some subtle hints of challenging handling model, namely in the need to rotate your vehicle in the air to ensure a safe/fast landing. The reward for taking that control is that you will get boost added to your gauge for every landing you make that is perfect.

The level design is pretty awesome as well. The tracks sprawl and are completely populated with tons of set pieces and hazards that make the race even more engaging. All of the tracks also employ sections that completely disregard gravity or the laws of physics, and it makes for some really fun sections of track.

Sound design is adequate, and the soundtrack is a pretty solid metal affair. It is in the game directory in OGG format, so that is pretty awesome as well.

To further the enjoyment, there are a wealth of new parts you can unlock and install on either your ATV or MTX vehicle. The interesting thing, unlike most racers with upgrades"
date: is that these parts aren't always a clear betterment to the ones you have installed. Each part carries some bonus or some malus with it
recommended: so it is up to you to choose the parts that will balance the various characterstics of your ride as you see fit. Really nice depth to tuning there.\n\nOverall

reviewText:
Boy, this is gonna an unpopular review, but... Nail'd is garbage.
I like this genre of racers-- the tricks, the constant speed, the excitement that so many others manage to capture. Why can't Nail'd do it?
Well, for one, because it's impossible to lose.

Even at the hardest difficulties, I never, ever finished in anything but first place. Even if I constantly crash my bike, I respawn farther ahead than I was before, so it doesn't set me back in the slightest.
I'd still manage to have fun if I could perform tricks, race to awesome music, or at least race on a decent track, but this is just so... boring.
There are no tricks in Nail'd. There's, um... going through gates. Those refill your nitrous. What skill.
The tracks are bland and repetitive. There's really not much else to say, is there? I might as well describe the flashlight on my desk. It's black, but the switch is dark blue. It's more interesting than this game.
The music's better off muted. There aren't many songs, and they all suck.

If you consider yourself a gamer of good taste, spare yourself and buy Mad Riders instead. It has a variety of tricks, a sense of speed, a more exciting soundtrack, and pretty maps. Much less of an eyesore than endless desert.

reviewText:
Nail'd could have been an average generic racer if it wasn't for a huge flaw: the driving mechanics.

Everything is unpredictable. The way the gravity will react, the way the vehicle is going to respond when landing after a jump, or even if you're going to grip or not. This makes for a very unpleasant experience, not helped by the amount of glitches. Sometimes you can pull one-wheel wheelies because the engine glitches, sometimes you will crash into invisible walls, sometimes you will crash face first while trying to land, and much more. This is why I can't recommend the game.

This is a shame, because it has all the basics for an enjoyable little racing game. The graphics are decent (apart for the ugly and nearly headache-inducing shake filter when boosting), sound design isn't too unpleasant and there are some interesting ride and rider customization options. The game still has the same faults you can find on pretty much every relatively low budget racing game:
- nail'd becomes a bit boring as you start powering through it. The limited amount of tracks (12) compared to amount of races (around 70-80) means you'll be going around the same tracks again and again, which completely nullifies the point of having branching tracks and scripted set pieces. You'll have to learn the optimal line around a track to be able to beat the AI.
- Horrible, inconsistent AI. The AI will teleport itself, it will drive through you, it will do impossible moves. But it will be slow nonetheless. There are only a couple of near end-game events where the AI cheats enough to be challenging. In most races, it's easy to gain a 5 second lead and never let go of it.
- Generic locations and art-style. While I did appreciate the mediterranean caricature, the three other environments are painfully generic. Generic desert area with huge rock formations and a western movie styled town. Generic jungle area with mud, too many trees and some wood bridges. Generic snow area with snow covered mountains. Generic vehicles with generic paintjobs.

On the technical side, since it's running on Techland's engine you'll have to deal with all sorts of bugs and issues depending on your configuration and the moon's phase.
